content:
python

# The pixel at 0,0 is red and we're using 8-bit color
myImage.getRedVal(0, 0) # Returns 255
myImage.getRed(0, 0) # Returns 1

colors = myImage.getXelVal(0,0) # Returns (255,0,0)
colorVal = myImage.getXel(0,0) # Returns (1,0,0)

The methods for setting pixel information are set_red(x, y, value) <.PNMImage.set_red>, set_green(x, y, value) <.PNMImage.set_green>, set_blue(x, y, value) <.PNMImage.set_blue>, set_xel(x, y, color) <.PNMImage.set_xel>, or set_red_val(x, y, value) <.PNMImage.set_red_val>, set_green_val(x, y, value) <.PNMImage.set_green_val>, set_blue_val(x, y, value) <.PNMImage.set_blue_val>, set_xel_val(x, y, color) <.PNMImage.set_xel_val>. The same as above applies regarding the dichotomy between the regular setters and the ones marked with "val". You can also fill an image with a color by using fill(r, g, b) <.PNMImage.fill> and fill_val(r, g, b) <.PNMImage.fill_val>.

python
